SOSEP works in coordination with the [[First Lady of Guatemala|First Lady of the Nation]], and the current first lady is [[Patricia Marroquín|Patricia Marroquin]], also follows the guidelines she has drawn. It was created on July 14, 1994, during the government of President [[Jorge Serrano Elías]], through government Article 893-91.http://www.minfin.gob.gt/index.php/?option=com_content&view=article&id=2078&Itemid=195{{cite web|url=http://www.sosep.gob.gt/|title=Sosep|website=www.sosep.gob.gt}}{{cite news|first=|last=|title= El antes y después de la esposa de Jimmy Morales, Patricia Marroquín de Morales |url=https://www.publinews.gt/gt/noticias/2016/02/17/despues-esposa-jimmy-morales-patricia-marroquin-morales.html |work=[[Publinews]] |publisher= |date=2016-02-17 |accessdate=2018-01-27}}{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Esposa da palabras de aliento a Jimmy Morales |url=http://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/politica/los-primeros-cien-dias-del-gobierno-segun-la-esposa-del-presidente |work=[[Prensa Libre]] |publisher= |date=2016-04-26 |accessdate=2018-01-27}}{{cite web|url=http://www.soy502.com/articulo/hoy-cumpleanos-primera-dama-ella-lo-celebro-asi-68696|title=Hoy es el cumpleaños de la Primera Dama y lo celebró así|publisher=}}http://transparencia.minfin.gob.gt/transparencia/BibliotecaDigital/Documentos%20Area%20Gubernamental/Sosep.pdf{{cite web|url=https://reliefweb.int/report/guatemala/designan-sosep-para-supervisar-albergues-para-ni%C3%B1os-en-%C3%A1reas-afectadas|title=Designan a Sosep para supervisar albergues para niños en áreas afectadas|publisher=}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Guatemala First Ladies}} {{Guatemala-stub}} [[Category:Government of Guatemala]] [[Category:Ministries of Guatemala|SOSEP]] [[Category:Public policy|Guatemala]]

'''Sex in advertising''' is the use of [[sex appeal]] in [[advertising]] to help sell a particular product or service. According to research, sexually appealing imagery does not need to pertain to the product or service in question. A few examples of sexually appealing imagery include [[nudity]], [[pin-up model]]s, and muscular men. "Sex sells" became a controversial issue, with techniques for enlarging and titillating the audience challenging conventional moral standards.<ref>Rodger Streitmatter, ''Sex sells!: The media's journey from repression to obsession'' (Basic Books, 2004).</ref><ref>Jessica Dawn Blair, et al., "Ethics in advertising: sex sells, but should it?." ''Journal of Legal, Ethical and Regulatory Issues'' 9.1/2 (2006): 109+.</ref>
In contemporary mainstream advertising (e.g., magazines, online, television), sex is present in promotional messages for a wide range of branded goods. Ads often feature provocative images of well-defined women (and men) in revealing outfits and postures selling things such as clothing, alcohol, beauty products, and fragrances. Advertisers such as Calvin Klein, Victoria's Secret, and Pepsi (just to name a few) use these images to cultivate a sexy media presence. Also, sexual information is used to promote mainstream products not traditionally associated with sex. For example, [[Dallas Opera]]'s recent reversal of its declining ticket sales has been attributed to the marketing of the more lascivious parts of its performances.<ref>Chism, 1999</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Sex in advertising research: A review of content, effects, and functions of sexual information in consumer advertising|year=2002|pages=241–73|journal=Annu. Rev. Sex Res.|volume=13|author=Tom Reichert|pmid=12836733}}</ref>
The use of sex in advertising can be highly overt or extremely subtle and, on some level, subliminal. It ranges from relatively explicit displays of sexual acts and seductive behavior aimed at the viewer, to the use of double-meanings and underlying sexual references that are more subconscious. Sex in advertising relies on evolutionary processes and varies in effectiveness depending on the culture and gender of the receiver. The use of sex in advertising has been criticized for its tendency to objectify the female body and emphasizing various stereotypes.
[[Image:Pearl, tobacco label, 1871.jpg|thumb|The earliest known use of sex in advertising, Pearl Tobacco label showing lightly draped female figure rising from the waves.]] [[File:SchraderAp1921.jpg|thumb|An early example of sexual imagery in advertising]]{{Marketing}}
==Concept== ''Gender Advertisements'',<ref>{{cite book |last1=Goffman |first1=Erving |title=Gender Advertisements |date=March 1, 1979 |publisher=Harper & Row |isbn=0060906332 |pages=84 |edition=1}}</ref> a 1979 book by Canadian social anthropologist, [[Erving Goffman]] is series of studies of visual communication and how gender representation in advertising communicates subtle, underlying messages about the sexual roles projected by masculine and feminine images in advertising. The book is a visual essay about sex roles in advertising and the differences, as well as the symbolism implied in the depictions of men and women in advertising.
When couples are used in an advertisement, the sex-roles played by each also send out messages. The interaction of the couple may send out a message of relative dominance and power, and may stereotype the roles of one or both partners. Usually the message is very subtle, and sometimes advertisements attract interest by changing stereotypical roles. For example, companies including [[Spotify]], [[AirBnB]], [[Lynx (web browser)|Lynx]] and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] have used same-sex couples in adverts.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Gareth|title=13 amazing adverts featuring same-sex couples|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2015/08/13/13-amazing-adverts-featuring-same-sex-couples/|website=PinkNews|accessdate=2016-11-22}}</ref> These adverts appeal to same-sex couples; and they also create the image that these companies are tolerant and allow them to appeal to a wider consumer audience.
As many consumers and professionals think, sex is used to grab a viewer's attention but this is a short-term success. Whether using sex in advertising is effective depends on the product.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brandingstrategyinsider.com/2008/03/does-sex-in-adv.html|title=DOES SEX IN ADVERTISING WORK?|publisher=Branding Strategy Insider|accessdate=2015-03-31|date=2008-03-22}}</ref> About three-quarters of advertisements using sex to sell the product are communicating a product-related benefit, such as the product making its users more sexually attractive. {{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==Types==
===Physical attractiveness=== The use of physically attractive models in advertising is a form of sex in advertising. Physical attractiveness can be conveyed through facial beauty, physique, hair, skin complexion as well as by the model's inferred personality. This form of sex in advertising is effective as it draws attention and influences the overall feeling of the ad. Furthermore, such ads create an association between physical attractiveness and the product which sends a message to the consumer buying it that they will help them achieve that physique.<ref name="Reichert">{{cite book|last1=Reichert|first1=Tom|title=Sex in advertising: Perspectives on the erotic appeal|date=2011|publisher=Routledge|pages=11–151}}</ref> The [[sexual arousal]] possibly elicited by physical attractiveness in adverts is thought to transfer onto the advertised product.<ref name="AABerger">{{cite book|last1=Berger|first1=Arthur Asa|title=Ads, fads and Consumer culture|date=2015|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|pages=99–120|edition=Fifth}}</ref>
===Sexual behaviour=== Marketers often use tactics such as using sexual imagery in their advertisements to capture the consumer's attention for longer.<ref>Dahl, Sengupta & Vohs (2009)</ref> Sex in advertising is also incorporated using hints of [[sexual behaviour]]. The latter is communicated by the models using flirtatious [[body language]], open posture and making eye contact with the viewer. Sexual behaviour can also be displayed using several models interacting in a more or less sexual way. Sexual behaviour in advertising is used to arouse sexual interest from the viewer.<ref name="Reichert" /> Research has shown that sexual arousal elicited by an advert subsequently affects the overall ad evaluation and the chances of future purchase.<ref name="AABerger" />
For example, in a Guess clothing advert, while the models are physically attractive, it is their behavior such as position, posture and facial expressions that communicate sexual interest to the viewer. Women are often shown as being shorter, put in the background of images, shown in more ‘feminine’ poses than men, and generally present a higher degree of ‘body display’ than men in print advertisements.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zotos|first=Yorgos|last2=Tsichla|first2=Eirini|date=October 2014|title=Snapshots of Men and Women in Interaction: An Investigation of Stereotypes in Print Advertisement Relationship Portrayals|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/267842958|journal=Journal of Euromarketing|volume=23|issue=3|pages=35–58|via=ResearchGate|doi=10.9768/0023.03.035}}</ref>
===Sexual referents=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:VW topless.png|thumb|282x282px|Volkswagen advert for the "topless" Beetle Cabriolet]] --> Sexual referents are a more implicit example of sex in advertising. Sex can be invoked in advertising using sexual double entendre or innuendos. The latter rely on the viewer to interpret them. They can be words or images that while not being explicitly sexual, trigger sexual thoughts from the viewer. Elements such as lighting, music, models’ behaviour and camera effects can contribute towards communicating implicit sexual meaning. Sexual referents are a powerful tool as they drive viewers to create sexual thoughts and interpretations of the product.<ref name="Reichert" />
While sexual referents are an implicit use of sex in advertising, as there may be nothing overtly sexual about them, they are placed by advertisers in the aim that viewers will interpret them as sexual.
An example of sexual referents is [[Volkswagen]]'s campaign for the [[Volkswagen Beetle|Beetle]] Cabriolet. The advert pixelates the non-existent roof to the car, similar to the pixilation that occurs when female's breasts are exposed in some forms of media. Volkswagen have a history of producing tongue-in-cheek adverts, and this one serves to compare their new convertible to a woman who goes topless at a beach. It implies the car is relaxed and fun, like someone who goes topless at a beach. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Super chocolate cake vagina Moist.jpg|left|thumb|168x168px|Betty Crocker cake mix advert using sexual embed technique]] -->
===Sexual embeds=== Sexual embeds are a controversial form of sex in advertising. They are a powerful technique that advertising agencies do not want consumers to consciously notice. They are [[subliminal stimuli|subliminal]] elements that are detected as sexual information solely at the subconscious level. Sexual embeds can take the form of objects or words that, at the subconscious level (or when occasionally consciously identified) explicitly depict sexual acts or genitalia. For example, a perfume bottle could mimic a phallic shape and its positioning could suggest sexual intercourse. Embeds are especially effective as they unconsciously trigger sexual arousal in the consumer which drives motivation and goal directed behaviour such as purchase intention.<ref name="Reichert" />
An example of this technique is a particular cake mix advertisement from [[Betty Crocker]] in which it would appear the chocolate icing on the heel of the cake has been painted to look like [[female genitalia]]. Amongst millions who viewed the commercial, very few will have noticed anything unusual; however, while this detail might not have been consciously perceived, it would have been interpreted sexually at the [[subconscious]] level. This advertisement, directed at women, puts an emphasis on the [[sense of touch]] by using words such as "moist", and on the whole the ad creates a subconscious association between the product and [[sexual pleasure]].<ref name="Reichert" />
===Gender roles=== After women achieved the vote in the United States, Britain and Canada in the 1920s, advertising agencies exploited the new status of women. For example, they associated driving an automobile with masculinity, power, control, and dominance over a beautiful woman sitting alongside. More subtly, they published automobile ads in women's magazines, at a time when the vast majority of purchasers and drivers were in fact men. The new ads promoted themes of women's liberation while also delineating the limits of this freedom. Automobiles were more than practical devices. They were also highly visible symbols of affluence, mobility and modernity. The ads offered women a visual vocabulary to imagine their new social and political roles as citizens and to play an active role in shaping their identity as modern women.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Einav | first1 = Rabinovitch-Fox | year = 2016 | title = Baby, You Can Drive My Car: Advertising Women's Freedom in 1920s America | url = | journal = American Journalism | volume = 33 | issue = 4| pages = 372–400 }}</ref>
== Evolutionary theory == [[File:AN Aurora Jolie 1.jpg|thumb|209x209px|An example of a product being paired with sexual imagery to create an association between the two. The logo of the product this model is promoting is printed on the [[pasties]] (on her breasts).]] Research into evolution explains the use of sex in advertising and the differences between genders, due to different [[Mating strategy|mating strategies]]. It is the biological prerogative of the male to reproduce with as many females as possible, as this increases his chances of producing [[offspring]]. Because of this need to reproduce as much as possible, males search for cues which signal females are available and accessible, such as seductive behaviour, as well as cues that indicate good health, including facial symmetry,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Thornhill & Gangstead|year=1996|title=The evolution of human sexuality|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/49758142|journal=Trends in Ecology and Evolution|volume=11|issue=2|pages=98–102|doi=10.1016/0169-5347(96)81051-2}}</ref> shiny hair and firm breasts.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Havlíček |first=Jan|display-authors=etal |year=2016|title=Men's preferences for women's breast size and shape in four cultures|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1090513816302847|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|volume=In Press|issue=2|pages=217–226|via=|doi=10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2016.10.002}}</ref> Advertisers can use these findings to help create an association between their product and the males needs by pairing the two.
Evolutionary research into female sex strategies show that women are more concerned about long term prospects and mates resources,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Buss |first=D |last2=Schmitt |first2=D.|year=1993|title=Sexual strategies theory: an evolutionary perspective on human mating|url=|journal=Psychological Review|volume=100.2|issue=2|pages=204–232|via=|doi=10.1037/0033-295x.100.2.204}}</ref> and less interested in typical male requirements of good health and accessibility. This explains why sexually explicit adverts tend to be directed at male consumers, whereas products aimed at a female market typically involve romantic imagery, and males who are wealthy, intelligent or powerful.
==History== {{main|History of advertising}} The earliest known use of sex in advertising is by the Pearl Tobacco brand in 1871, which featured a naked maiden on the package cover. In 1885, W. Duke & Sons inserted trading cards into cigarette packs that featured sexually provocative starlets. Duke grew to become the leading American cigarette brand by 1890.<ref>Porter, 1971</ref> [[File:1916-skin-touch-soap-ad.jpg|thumb|320x320px|1916 ''Ladies' Home Journal'' version of the famous seduction-based ad by [[Helen Lansdowne Resor]] at J. Walter Thompson Agency]] Other early forms of sex appeal in advertising include woodcuts and illustrations of attractive women (often unclothed from the waist up) adorning posters, signs, and ads for [[bar (establishment)|saloon]]s, [[patent medicine|tonic]]s, and [[tobacco]]. In several notable cases, sex in advertising has been claimed as the reason for increased consumer interest and sales.
===Sex and soap=== [[Woodbury's Facial Soap]], a woman's beauty bar, was almost discontinued in 1911. The soap's sales decline was reversed, however, with ads containing images of romantic couples and promises of love and intimacy for those using the brand.<ref>''Account Histories'', 1926</ref> Jovan Musk Oil, introduced in 1971, was promoted with sexual entendre and descriptions of the fragrance's sexual attraction properties. As a result, Jovane, Inc.'s revenue grew from $1.5 million in 1971 to $77 million by 1978.<ref>Sloan & Millman, 1979</ref>
===KamaSutra condoms in India=== In 1991, J.K. Chemicals Group asked the [[Bombay]] office of Lintas Bombay to develop a campaign for a new [[condom]] brand. The problem was that in the late 1940s, the [[Nehru]] government had launched a major population limitation program to reduce India's birthrate. The program was very heavy-handed, using coercion, and demanding that men use condoms. The product therefore signified an oppressive governmental intrusion. The agency head hit on the idea of a pleasurable condom, "So when the user hears the brand name, he says, "Wow. It's a turn on. Not a turn off." A brainstorming session hit on the name "[[KamaSutra (brand)|KamaSutra]]", which refers to [[Kama Sutra|an ancient Sanskrit treatise on lovemaking]] and the sculptures at temples that illustrate the positions involved. The term was known to well-educated Indians, and that was the intended audience. Correctly predicting the huge impact the ad campaign would have, the agency purchased all the advertising space in the popular glamour magazine ''[[Debonair (magazine)|Debonair]]'' and filled it with erotic images of [[Bollywood]] actors and actresses promoting KamaSutra condoms. A television commercial followed featuring a steamy shower scene. The television ad was censored but the print campaign proved highly successful.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = O'Barr | first1 = William M. | year = 2008 | title = Advertising in India | url = | journal = Advertising & Society Review | volume = 9 | issue = 3 }}</ref><ref>William Mazzarella, ''Shoveling Smoke: Advertising and Globalization in Contemporary India'' (Duke University Press, 2003)</ref>
===Benetton=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Priest Benetton Nun.jpg|thumb|190x190px|Nun and Priest kissing in a Benetton United Colours advert]] --> The Italian clothing company [[Benetton Group|Benetton]] gained worldwide attention in the late 20th century for its saucy advertising, inspired by its art director [[Oliviero Toscani]]. He started with multicultural themes, tied together under the campaign "United Colors of Benetton" then became increasingly provocative with interracial groupings, and unusual sexual images, such as a nun kissing a priest.<ref>Mark Tungate, ''Adland: A Global History of Advertising'' (2007) pp 146–49</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Brooke shields calvin klein jeans.jpg|left|thumb|268x268px|Calvin Klein advert featuring Brooke Shields]] -->
===Calvin Klein - sex and jeans=== [[Calvin Klein]] of '''Calvin Klein [[Jeans]]''' has been at the forefront of this movement to use sex in advertising, having claimed, "Jeans are about sex. The abundance of bare flesh is the last gasp of advertisers trying to give redundant products a new identity." Calvin Klein's first controversial jeans advertisement showed a 15-year-old [[Brooke Shields]], in Calvin Klein jeans, saying, "Do you want to know what gets between me and my Calvins? Nothing."<ref>{{cite news |last=Sischy |first=Ingrid |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2008/04/calvin200804?currentPage=7 |title=Vanity Fair Calvin Klein |publisher=Vanityfair.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-28}}</ref> [[Calvin Klein]] has also received media attention for its controversial advertisements in the mid-1990s. Several of Calvin Klein's advertisements featured images of teenage models, some "who were reportedly as young as 15" in overly sexual and provocative poses.<ref name="Calvin Klein: A Case Study">[http://www.media-awareness.ca/english/resources/educational/handouts/ethics/calvin_klein_case_study.cfm Calvin Klein: A Case Study] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120521174126/http://www.media-awareness.ca/english/resources/educational/handouts/ethics/calvin_klein_case_study.cfm |date=2012-05-21 }}</ref> Although Klein insisted that these advertisements were not pornographic, some considered the campaign as a form of "[[soft porn]]" or "[[kiddie porn]]" that was exploitative, shocking, and suggestive. In 1999, Calvin Klein was the subject of more controversy when it aired advertisements of young children who were only wearing the brand's underwear. This "kiddie underwear ad campaign" was pulled only one day after it aired as a result of public outlash.<ref>Peters, Robert. [http://store.soliscompany.com/kpoco.html "Kiddie Porn" Controversy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725074812/http://store.soliscompany.com/kpoco.html |date=2009-07-25 }}</ref> A spokesperson from Calvin Klein insisted that these ads were intended "to capture the same warmth and spontaneity that you find in a family snapshot."<ref name="Calvin Klein: A Case Study"/>
==Effectiveness==
===Effective use=== Gallup & Robinson, an advertising and marketing research firm, has reported that in more than 50 years of testing advertising effectiveness, it has found the use of the erotic to be a significantly above-average technique in communicating with the marketplace, "...although one of the more dangerous for the advertiser. Weighted down with taboos and volatile attitudes, sex is a Code Red advertising technique ... handle with care ... seller beware; all of which makes it even more intriguing." This research has led to the popular idea that ''"sex sells"''.<ref name="Sex sells">{{Cite book|title=Sex sells!: The media's journey from repression to obsession|last=Streitmatter|first=Roger|publisher=Basic Books|year=2004|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
Marketing strategies centred around sex have been successful. [[Abercrombie & Fitch]] used sex to market their brand in a variety of ways, including store greeters dressed only in underwear, models working in store and topless models on the bags. Employees were hired based on physical attractiveness.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2015/05/07/abercrombie-and-fitch-hollister-sexual-marketing/70934572/|title=Cover up! Abercrombie & Fitch says sexual marketing is over|website=USA today|last1=Bowerman|first1=Mary|accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> This strategy was aimed at teenagers and young adults, who are the most impressionable consumer group, and who have vast amounts of disposable money. During the late 1990s, the company produced a magazine/catalogue (magalog), featuring semi-nude or nude models. The magalog was a success, with A&F issuing over 1.5 million copies. Despite being somewhat paradoxical, the use of sexual branding raised their revenue from $85 million in 1993 to $1.35 billion in 2002.<ref>{{cite journal|date=2005|title=Message Communication in Advertising: Selling the Abercrombie and Fitch Image|url=https://www.uwlax.edu/urc/jur-online/PDF/2005/driessen.pdf|journal=UW-L Journal of Undergraduate Research VIII|last1=Driessen|first1=Claire|accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref> A&F have expressed that they will move away from sexual marketing, and focus on showcasing product and trends.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/shirts-boys-abercrombie-says-its-done-sexualized-marketing-164300|title=Shirts on, Boys. Abercrombie Says It's Done With Sexualized Marketing|website=Adweek.com|last1=Monllos|first1=Kristina|accessdate=2016-11-23}}</ref>
Sexuality in advertising is extremely effective at attracting the consumer's attention and once it has their attention, to remember the message.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=King|first=James|last2=McClelland|first2=Alastair|last3=Furnham|first3=Adrian|date=2015-03-01|title=Sex Really Does Sell: The Recall of Sexual and Non-sexual Television Advertisements in Sexual and Non-sexual Programmes|journal=Applied Cognitive Psychology|language=en|volume=29|issue=2|pages=210–216|doi=10.1002/acp.3095|issn=1099-0720}}</ref> This solves the greatest problem in advertising of getting the potential buyer to look at and remember the advertisement. However the introduction of attraction and especially sexuality into an ad often distracts from the original message and can cause an adverse effect of the consumer wanting to take action.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.acrwebsite.org/search/view-conference-proceedings.aspx?Id=6040|title=Sexual Content and Advertising Effectiveness: Comments on Belch Et Al. (1981) and Caccavale Et Al. (1981) by Robert S. Baron|journal=Acr North American Advances|volume=NA-09|accessdate=2015-03-31|year=1982|last1=Baron|first1=Robert S.}}</ref>
=== Ineffective use === [[File:1926BestLikedPhotosInTheWorld.jpg|thumb|1926 US advertisement for [[French postcard|"French" postcards]]]]
There are some studies that contradict the theory that sex is an effective tool for improving finances and gathering attention. A study from 2009 found that there was a negative correlation between nudity and sexuality in movies, and box office performance and critical acclaim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/pubs/journals/releases/aca-3-4-200.pdf |title=Sex Doesn't Sell—Nor Impress! Content, Box Office, Critics, and Awards in Mainstream Cinema|date=2009|author=Anemone Cerridwen, Dean Keith Simonton |format=PDF |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref> A 2005 research by MediaAnalyzer has found that less than 10% of men recalled the brand of sexual ads, compared to more than 19% of non sexual ads; a similar result was found in women (10.8% vs. 22.3%). It is hypothesized by that survey, that this is a result of a general numbing caused by over use of [[sexual stimuli]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emergencemarketing.com/2005/10/25/sex-in-ads-does-not-sell/ |title=Sex in ads does not sell |publisher=Emergencemarketing.com |date=2005-10-25 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref> in advertising.
In another experimental study conducted on 324 undergraduate college students, [[Brad Bushman]] examined brand recall for neutral, sexual or violent commercials embedded in neutral, sexual or violent TV programs. He found that brand recall was higher for participants who saw neutral TV programs and neutral commercials versus those who saw sexual or violent commercials embedded in sexual or violent TV programs.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bushman|first=Brad|title=That was a great commercial, but what were they selling? Effects of violence and sex on memory for products in television commercials.|journal=Journal of Applied Social Psychology|year=2007|volume=37|issue=8|pages=1784–1796|doi=10.1111/j.1559-1816.2007.00237.x|hdl=1871/39449}}</ref> Other studies have found that sex in television is extremely overrated and does not sell products in ads. Unless sex is related to the product (such as beauty, health or hygiene products) there is not clear effect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.uga.edu/releases/article/magazine-trends-study-finds-increase-in-advertisements-using-sex/|title=Magazine trends study finds increase in advertisements using sex|date=2012-06-05|publisher=uga.edu|accessdate=2012-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/7624485|title=Violence and Sex in Television Programs Do Not Sell Products in Advertisements|date=2012-06-05|publisher=researchgate.net|accessdate=2012-06-05}}</ref>
Using sex may attract one market demographic while repelling another at the same time. The overt use of sexuality to promote [[breast cancer awareness]], through fundraising campaigns like "I Love Boobies" and "Save the Ta-tas", is effective at reaching younger women, who are at low risk of developing breast cancer, but angers and offends some breast [[cancer survivor]]s and older women, who are at higher risk of developing breast cancer.<ref name="Szabo">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/10/30/patients-decry-sexualization-of-breast-cancer/1630911/ |title=Sexy breast cancer campaigns anger many patients|last=Szabo|first=Lisa|date=30 October 2012 |work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref>
=== Gender differences ===
Recent research indicates that the use of sexual images of females in ads negatively affects women's interest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://medicalxpress.com/news/2013-12-women-sexually-explicit-ads-unappealingunless.html#inlRlv |title=Women find sexually explicit ads unappealing—unless the price is right |publisher=medicalxpress.com |date=2013-12-03 |accessdate=2013-12-03}}</ref> Research shows that females were more likely than males to be portrayed as nude, wearing sexual clothing or only a partial amount of clothing.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Soley|first=Lawrence|year=1986|title=Sex in Advertising: A Comparison of 1964 and 1984 Magazine Advertisements|url=|journal=Journal of Advertising|volume=15|issue=3|pages=46–64|via=|doi=10.1080/00913367.1986.10673018}}</ref> A study from the [[University of Minnesota]] in 2013 of how printed ads with sexual content affects women clearly showed that women are not attracted to them except in the case of products being luxurious and expensive.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/sex-doesnt-sell-this-study-into-womens-response-to-raunchy-advertising-starts-wrong-and-gets-worse-8995776.html |title=Sex doesn't sell? This study into women's response to raunchy advertising starts wrong and gets worse|publisher=www.independent.co.uk |date=2013-12-10 |accessdate=2013-12-10}}</ref> Besides alienating women there is a serious risk that the audience in general will reduce support to organisations that uses the sexual images of women without a legitimate reason.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://phys.org/news/2013-12-sex.html |title=Study: Does sex always sell?|publisher=phys.org |date=2013-12-19 |accessdate=2013-12-19}}</ref>
Further research <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sengupta|first=J|year=2008|title=Gender-related reactions to gratuitous sex appeals in advertising|url=|journal=Journal of Consumer Advertising|volume=18|pages=62–78|via=|doi=10.1016/j.jcps.2007.10.010}}</ref> found that men have a positive attitude to sexual adverts, whereas women have a negative response to them, this study used an advert with both a male and female. This was thought to be because women had lower average [[sex drive]]<nowiki/>s than men. Another theory for this difference is that evolution has led men to seek casual sex, contrary to women who value commitment and intimacy in the context of a sexual relationship.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Herold|year=1993|title=Gender differences in casual sex and AIDS prevention: A survey of dating bars.|url=|journal=Journal of Sex Research|volume=30|pages=36–42|via=|doi=10.1080/00224499309551676}}</ref> In adverts sex tends to be represented in its own right and not as part of a relationship leading to the difference in responses. This theory is supported by research which found that women respond less negatively to sexual adverts when it is in the context of gift giving from a man to a women. Therefore, react less negatively when the sexuality of the advert is the context of commitment. Men respond more negatively to the sexual advert when it involves gift giving as it emphasises them having to spend money in a relationship.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dahl|first=Darren|year=2009|title=Sex in advertising: Gender differences and the role of relationship commitment|url=|journal=Journal of Consumer Research|volume=36|issue=2|pages=215–231|via=|doi=10.1086/597158|citeseerx=10.1.1.620.2353}}</ref> This is in line with evolutionary theory that women value men for their resources and men value women for sex and fertility <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Buss|first=David|year=1989|title=Sex differences in human mate preferences: Evolutionary hypotheses tested in 37 cultures|url=|journal=Behavioral and Brain Sciences|volume=12|pages=1–14|via=|doi=10.1017/s0140525x00023992}}</ref> Further research found that even in men recall of the advert is worsened by sexual content, as they focus on breasts and legs but not on the product.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nudd|year=2005|title=Does sex really sell?|url=|journal=Adweek|volume=46|pages=14–17|via=}}</ref>
=== Cultural differences === In order to be consistent, brands use standardized campaigns across various countries.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Argawal|first=Wadhu|year=1995|title=Review of a 40-year debate in international advertising: Practitioner and academician perspectives to the standardization/adaptation issue|journal=International Marketing Review|volume=12|pages=26–48|doi=10.1108/02651339510080089}}</ref> Cultural differences have been found in response to sexual adverts. A 2016 study by the Korea Internet Advertising Foundation (KIAF) noted that 94.5% of South Korean high schoolers were familiar with sex-driven ads, 83.4% of adults thought such ads have negative influence on society, and 91.2% said there are too many of such ads. A KIAF official noted that government legislation aimed to reduce such ads is not effective due to its ambiguity.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://koreabizwire.com/internet-ads-with-sexual-imagery-at-a-critical-level-survey/65968?platform=hootsuite|title=Internet Ads with Sexual Imagery at a Critical Level: Survey {{!}} Be Korea-savvy|website=koreabizwire.com|access-date=2016-09-12}}</ref> Research has found that sex is used in adverts more in [[France]] than in the [[United States]] because they are more sexually liberated and so receptive to its use in advertising.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Biswas|year=1992|title=A comparison of print advertisements from the United States and France|url=|journal=Journal of Advertising|volume=21|issue=4|pages=73–81|doi=10.1080/00913367.1992.10673387}}</ref>
==Prevalence== In the [[21st century]], the use of increasingly explicit sexual imagery in consumer-oriented print ads have become almost commonplace. Ads for jeans, [[perfume]]s and many other products have featured provocative images that were designed to elicit sexual responses from as large a cross section of the population as possible, to shock by their ambivalence, or to appeal to repressed sexual desires, which are thought to carry a stronger emotional load. Increased tolerance, more tempered censorship, emancipatory developments and increasing buying power of previously neglected appreciative target groups in rich markets (mainly in the West) have led to a marked increase in the share of attractive flesh 'on display'.
''[[Advertising Age|Ad Age]]'', a magazine delivering news, analysis, and data on marketing and media, published a list of Top 100 most effective advertising of the century, out of the 100, only 8 involved use of sex.<ref name=Garfield>{{cite news |author=Garfield, Bob |date=29 March 1999 |title=Top 100 Advertising Campaigns of the Century |url=http://adage.com/century/campaigns.html |newspaper=Ad Age|accessdate=2015-03-31}}</ref>
Unruly Media's viral video tracker lists the Top-20 most viewed car commercial viral videos. Only 1 uses sex, while the No.1 spot was held by VW's "The Force" ad.<ref>{{cite web |title=Top-20 most popular car commercials |url=http://mememachine.viralvideochart.com/blog/2011/8/17/top-20-most-popular-car-commercials.html |publisher=Unruly Media |accessdate=2015-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811141649/http://mememachine.viralvideochart.com/blog/2011/8/17/top-20-most-popular-car-commercials.html |archivedate=2014-08-11 |df= }}</ref> The overall top-spot (across all product segments), was held by VW's "Fun Theory" campaign, the most viewed viral video as of October 2011.
In international perspective, a 2008 comparison of nudity in television advertising in [[Brazil]], [[Canada]], [[China]], [[Germany]], [[South Korea]], [[Thailand]], and the [[United States]] reveals that China and the United States have the most demure ads, while Germany and Thailand exposed more of the female body. There is little variation in male undress.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Nelson | first1 = Michelle R. | last2 = Paek | first2 = Hye-Jin | year = 2008 | title = Nudity of female and male models in primetime TV advertising across seven countries | url = | journal = International Journal of Advertising | volume = 27 | issue = 5| pages = 715–744 | doi=10.2501/s0265048708080281}}</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:New zealand aids foundation Riding hard.jpg|thumb|"Riding Hard", part of the New Zealand AIDS Foundation's #loveyourcondom campaign]] --> Historically, sex in advertising has focused on heterosexual gender roles, but there are increasing examples of sex being used to advertise to the [[LGBT]] community. The New Zealand Aids Foundation's Love Your Condom (LYC) campaign used provocative images of males alongside captions such as "Riding hard?", "Bear hunting?" and "Going deep?", followed by the hashtag #loveyourcondom.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.loveyourcondom.co.nz/condoms|title=Order free condoms|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=New Zealand Aids Foundation|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> It was hoped by using images explicitly directed towards homosexual men, their use of condoms would increase, which would help decrease rates of HIV transmission amongst gay and bisexual men. The campaign has been successful, with a 12% in new [[HIV]] infections among [[Men who have sex with men|MSM]] in [[New Zealand]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=New Zealand Aids Foundation |title=History of NZAF |url=https://www.nzaf.org.nz/about-us/history-of-nzaf/|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
In a study conducted at the University of Georgia in 2003, researchers looked at sexual advertisements in magazines over the span of the last 30 years. The rate at which sex in advertising is being used increased from 15% to 27% in the advertisements that the researchers looked at. Their reasoning behind the increase is because they believe sex still sells, specifically with “low-risk products impulse purchases.” The study also mentions “alcohol, entertainment and beauty are the main product categories that use sex in advertising.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessnewsdaily.com/2649-sex-sells-more.html|title=Why Sex Sells…More Than Ever|newspaper=Business News Daily|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref>
==Criticism==
=== Stereotypes=== The use of sex in advertising has been criticized for its tendency to reinforce sexist stereotypes. Since the late 1970s, many researchers have determined that advertisements depict women as having less social power than men, but the ways in which females are displayed as less powerful than men have evolved over time. In modern times, advertisements have displayed women's expanding roles in the professional realm and importance in business backgrounds. However, as this change occurred there has been a substantial increase in the number of images that showcase women as less sexually powerful than men and as objects of men's desire.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stankiewicz and Rosselli|first1=Julie and Francine|title=Women as Sex Objects and Victims in Print Advertisements|journal=Sex Roles|date=2008|issue=58.7|pages=579–589|doi=10.1007/s11199-007-9359-1|volume=58}}</ref>
=== Objectification ===
Furthermore, sex in advertising has been criticised for its emphasis on the importance of physical attractiveness and role as mate. This emphasis has led men and women to value intelligence and general skills less.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Advertising and Society|last=Pardun|first=Carol|publisher=|year=2013|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> The rise in awareness of sexism portrayed in these types of adverts has led to stricter advertising policies. One group that enforces these rules is the [[Advertising Women of New York]] association. Adverts using highly sexual images containing nudity and unrealistic physiques can lead to self-objectification.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Roberts|year=2004|title=Mere exposure:effects of priming a state of self-objectification|url=|journal=Sex Roles|volume=51|pages=17–28|via=|doi=10.1023/b:sers.0000032306.20462.22}}</ref> In turn, this can lead to shame, disgust, appearance anxiety, eating disorders and depression. The increase in self-objectification caused by the use of sex in advertising has been found in women and men. The latter is not surprising with the increased sexual portrayal of men in advertising.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Reichart|first=Tom|year=1999|title=Cheesecake and beefcake: No matter how you slice it, sexual explicitness in advertising continues to increase.|url=|journal=Journalism & Mass Communication Quarterly|volume=76|pages=7–20|via=}}</ref>
=== Social norms ===
Sex in advertising is an accepted marketing technique however it is not unusual for it to cause backlash when it breaks social norms. In 1995, the Calvin Klein advertising campaign (see section on Calvin Klein, above) that showed teenage models in provocative poses wearing Calvin Klein underwear and jeans was deemed inappropriate and shocking. The ads were withdrawn when parents and child welfare groups threatened to protest and Hudson stores did not want their stores associated with the ads. It was reported that the [[US Justice Department]] was investigating the ad campaign for possible violations of federal child pornography and exploitation laws. The Justice Department subsequently decided not to prosecute Calvin Klein for these alleged violations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-11-16/business/fi-3736_1_calvin-klein|title=Justice Department Plans No Charges Over Calvin Klein Ads|publisher=Articles.latimes.com|accessdate=2015-03-31|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=1995-11-16}}</ref>
=== Skyy Vodka === [[Skyy Vodka]] is known for using sex in their advertising.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://epowers1.blogspot.com/2012/02/i-think-we-can-all-agree-with-statement.html|title=Liz's Media Criticism Blog: Skyy Ad Campaign Sells More Than Just Vodka|last=Powers|first=Liz|date=2012-02-16|website=Liz's Media Criticism Blog|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=April 2017}} In a specific Skyy Vodka advertisement, which was a part of Skyy Vodkas “SKYY SEXY” campaign in 2010,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20100928006244/en/CORRECTING-REPLACING-Skyy-Spirits-Unveils-Sexiest-Ad|title=CORRECTING and REPLACING Skyy Spirits Unveils Sexiest Ad Campaign in SKYY® Vodka History {{!}} Business Wire|website=www.businesswire.com|access-date=2016-12-12|date=2010-09-28}}</ref> a woman's legs are wrapped around a bottle of Skyy Vodka. Bruce Lee Livingston, of the [[Marin Institute]] stated “This is just ridiculous, It’s a porn-a-hol”.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/advertising/2010-09-28-vodka28_ST_N.htm|title=Skyy pushes the envelope with sexy ad campaign - USATODAY.com|website=usatoday30.usatoday.com|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref> He continues to mention its affect on underage kids. “Underage kids will look at this and associate sexual prowess with drinking Skyy.”<ref name=":1" /> Skyy Vodka’s marketing director, Maura McGinn, defended the advertisement by stating, “It’s the content of our product...We’re an adult product consumed mostly in the evenings and in flirtatious situations.” McGinn even defended the advertisement when pitted against the Distilled Spirits Council of the U.S. ad code that states, “Beverage alcohol advertising and marketing materials should not rely upon sexual prowess or sexual success as a selling point for the brand.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.discus.org/responsibility/code/|title=Code of Responsible Practices {{!}} DISCUS|website=www.discus.org|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref> McGinn stated “There is nothing in our ad that would suggest we are making such a claim.”<ref name=":1" />

{{unreferenced|date=September 2015}} '''Therapy freedom''' is the freedom of [[physicians]] to apply whichever therapy their medical knowledge makes them believe to be appropriate. That often means: # Physician have the [[legal right]] to prescribe an unlicensed drug. # A [[health insurance company]] is obliged to pay for the treatment, regardless of whether or not it considers the treatment to be appropriate.
Therapy freedom, however, is limited to cases of no treatment existing that is both well-established and more [[efficacious]].
Therapy freedom is established in [[Germany]], where it is known as ''[[:de:Therapiefreiheit|Therapiefreiheit]]''.

[[Springville, Alabama|Springville]], [[Alabama]] | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = | known_for = Participant in the [[16th Street Baptist Church bombing]] | height = | weight = | predecessor = | successor = | criminal_charge = Murder | conviction_status = | spouse = | children = | parents = Thomas Edwin "Pops" Blanton Sr. | motive = White supremacy | conviction = Murder | reward_amount = | capture_status = | wanted_by = | partners = {{Plainlist| * [[Robert Edward Chambliss]] * [[Herman Frank Cash]] * [[Bobby Frank Cherry]] }} | wanted_since = | time_at_large = | escaped = | escape_end = | comments = | apprehended = | imprisoned = | footnotes = | religion = | penalty = Life imprisonment }}'''Thomas Edwin Blanton Jr.''' (born 1938) is an American terrorist and convicted felon, currently serving a life sentence for his role as conspirator in the [[16th Street Baptist Church bombing]] in 1963 which killed four young [[African-American]] girls (Carole Robertson, Cynthia Wesley, Addie Mae Collins, and Denise McNair).{{cite news | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A03EEDB1438F931A35756C0A9679C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all | title=Ex-Klansman Is Found Guilty in '63 Bombing | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=May 2, 2001 | first=Kevin | last=Sack | accessdate = February 5, 2009}} Blanton, along with [[Bobby Frank Cherry]], was convicted in a highly-publicized trial in 2001. == Early life == Blanton is the son of Thomas Edwin "Pops" Blanton Sr., who was a notorious racist in the [[Birmingham, Alabama]] area.{{cite news|last1=Clary|first1=Mike|title=Birmingham's Painful Past Reopened|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/apr/14/news/mn-50901|accessdate=21 June 2014|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=14 April 2001}} == Trial and imprisonment == Blanton was convicted of murder in 2001 and sentenced to life in prison, with the eventual possibility of parole. His [[Alabama Department of Corrections]] AIS is 00216691. He is housed at [[St. Clair Correctional Facility]] in [[Springville, Alabama|Springville]], [[Alabama]].{{cite web|url=http://www.doc.state.al.us/InmateInfo?AIS=00216691|title=Thomas Edwin Blanton Jr.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Alabama Department of Corrections]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=Sep 15, 2013}} Blanton went before the parole board on August 3, 2016. '''Thracian clothing''' refers to types of clothing worn mainly by [[Thracians]], [[Dacians]]<ref name="Webber18">The Thracians 700 BC-AD 46 (Men-at-Arms) by Christopher Webber and Angus McBride, 2001, {{ISBN|1-84176-329-2}}, page 18</ref> but also by some [[Greeks]].<ref>[http://old.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/image?lookup=1992.11.0055&type=vase Greek warrior]</ref> Its best literal descriptions are given by [[Herodotus]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hdt.%207.75&lang=original|title=Herodotus, Histories 7.75|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and [[Xenophon]] in his [[Anabasis (Xenophon)|Anabasis]].<ref name="Webber18"/> Depictions are found in a great number of Greek vases and there are a few [[Persia]]n representations as well. In contrast to shapes and patterns we have very little evidence on the colours used.
== History and types == The Thracians wore a [[tunic]], a cloak called ''zeira'' ([[Ancient Greek]]: ζείρα), a cap called ''[[alopekis]]'' ([[Ancient Greek]]: Αλωπεκίς) made from the scalp of a fox with the ears visible,<ref name="Webber18"/> other [[Phrygian cap]] styles, and fawnskin boots called ''embades'' ([[Ancient Greek]]: Εμβάδες). Thracian clothing was sometimes decorated with intricate patterns. While [[pattern]]ed clothing was not unique to Thracians, the ''zeira'', ''embades'' and the ''alopekis'' probably originated from them.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} Clothing was made from hemp, flax or wool.<ref>The Thracians 700 BC-AD 46 (Men-at-Arms) by Christopher Webber and Angus McBride, 2001, {{ISBN|1-84176-329-2}}, page 17</ref> The [[Dacians]] and the [[Getae]] wore pantaloons called [[bracae]]<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0062:entry=bracae-harpers&highlight=dacians bracae-harpers]</ref> ([[Ancient Greek]],"''ἀναξυρίδες''" or "''θύλακοι''").These loose pants were described in Euripides work as “variegated bags” ([[Ancient Greek]],"''τοὺς θυλάκους τοὺς ποικίλους''") and may have appeared highly ridiculous to the Greeks, although [[Ovid]] mentions the adoption of them by the descendants of some of the Greek colonists on the Euxine.These trousers were common in many nations.
===Classical era=== [[File:Peltaste.JPG|thumb|right|Thracian [[peltast]] from a [[kylix (drinking cup)|kylix]] wearing patterned clothing]] In the north only noble Thracians, the "[[Zibythides]]" and noble [[Dacians]], the "[[Pileati]]", would wear caps.<ref name="Webber18"/> Despite this [[Herodotus]] writes that all Thracians in the [[Persian army]] wore foxskin caps and multicoloured mantles. Northern tribes in general, both Thracians and [[Daco-Getians]], wore clothes similar to [[Scythians]].<ref name="Webber18"/>
===Hellenistic era=== The Thracians at [[Battle of Pydna|Pydna]] in 168 BC wore black tunics. The [[Kausia]] ([[Ancient Greek]]: Καυσία) was adopted from the [[Macedon]]ians<ref>Saatsoglou-Paliadeli, Chryssoula. 1993. “Aspects of ancient Macedonian costume.” ''Journal of Hellenic Studies'' 113: 122–147. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/632401 doi:10.2307/632401]</ref>. Although many Thracian tribes began to incorporate Greek garbs to their fashion, they still largely retained their own styles of clothing.<ref>The Thracians 700 BC-AD 46 (Men-at-Arms) by Christopher Webber and Angus McBride, 2001, {{ISBN|1-84176-329-2}}, page 19</ref>

The '''USA Gymnastics sex abuse scandal''' involves the [[sexual abuse]] of female athletes—primarily minors—over the past two decades, in which over 368 individuals have been sexually assaulted "by gym owners, coaches, and staff working for gymnastics programs across the country".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/gvqm7y/skandal-u-americkoj-gimnastici-deca-zlostavljana-20-godina|title=New Report Reveals 20-Year Sex Abuse Scandal Across US Gymnastics Programs|last=Messman|first=Lauren|date=15 December 2016|publisher=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|language=English|accessdate=17 February 2018|quote=At least 368 child gymnasts have alleged sexual assault by gym owners, coaches, and staff working for top gymnastics programs across the country over the last 20 years.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/news/2016/12/15/20-year-toll-368-gymnasts-allege-sexual-exploitation/95198724/|title=A 20-year toll: 368 gymnasts allege sexual exploitation|year=2016|publisher=[[The Indianapolis Star]]|language=English|accessdate=17 February 2018|author=Tim Evans, Mark Alesia and Marisa Kwiatkowski|quote=At least 368 gymnasts have alleged some form of sexual abuse at the hands of their coaches, gym owners and other adults working in gymnastics. That's a rate of one every 20 days. And it's likely an undercount.}}</ref>
Particularly, [[Larry Nassar]], a former [[USA Gymnastics]] (USAG) national team [[osteopathic physician]], has been named in hundreds of lawsuits filed by athletes who said that Nassar sexually abused them under the pretense of providing medical treatment. Since the first public statements were made in September 2016, more than 265 women,<ref name = "hundreds">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-42894833|title=Larry Nassar case: USA Gymnastics doctor 'abused 265 girls'|work=BBC News|date=January 31, 2018}}</ref> including former [[United States women's national gymnastics team|USAG national team]] members [[Jamie Dantzscher]], Morgan White, [[Jeanette Antolin]], [[McKayla Maroney]], [[Aly Raisman]], [[Maggie Nichols (gymnast)|Maggie Nichols]], [[Gabby Douglas]], [[Simone Biles]], [[Jordyn Wieber]], [[Sabrina Vega]], [[Ashton Locklear]], [[Kyla Ross]], [[Madison Kocian]], [[Amanda Jetter]], [[Tasha Schwikert]], [[Mattie Larson]], [[Bailie Key]], [[Kennedy Baker]], and [[Alyssa Baumann]] have accused Nassar of sexually assaulting them. It is one of the biggest sexual abuse scandals in sports history.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/19/sports/olympics/nassar-gymnastics-raisman.html|title=Who Has U.S.A. Gymnastics' Back at This Point? The U.S.O.C., for Some Reason|work=The New York Times|date=January 19, 2018|first=Juliet|last=Macur}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://time.com/5113091/usa-gymnastics-board-members-resignation-larry-nassar/|title=USA Gymnastics Board Members Resign Amid Larry Nassar Sexual Abuse Scandal|work=Time|date=January 22, 2018|first=Alice|last=Park}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/dec/16/gymnastics-larry-nassar-sexual-abuse|title=Why don't we care about the biggest sex abuse scandal in sports history?|work=The Guardian|date=December 16, 2017|first=Bryan Armen|last=Graham}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2017/11/29/michigan-state-accused-covering-up-worst-sex-abuse-scandal-in-us-sports.html|title=Michigan State accused of covering up worst sex abuse scandal in US sports|work=Fox News|first=Caleb|last=Parke|date=November 30, 2017}}</ref> On July 11, 2017, Nassar pleaded guilty to federal [[child pornography]] charges; he was sentenced to 60 years in prison on December 7, 2017. On November 22, 2017, he pleaded guilty to seven charges of first-degree sexual assault and entered another guilty plea a week later to three additional charges of sexual assault. On January 24, 2018, Nassar was sentenced to an additional 40 to 175 years in prison, set to run after Nassar serves the 60-year federal prison sentence for child pornography. On February 5, 2018, Nassar received another 40 to 125 years.
An investigation over the period of nine months found that "predatory coaches were allowed to move from gym to gym, undetected by a lax system of oversight, or dangerously passed on by USA Gymnastics-certified gyms".<ref name="TIS2016"/> USAG and [[Michigan State University]]—where Nassar was a faculty member—have been accused of enabling Nassar's abuse<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/national-international/Larry-Nassar-Fallout-Michigan-State-US-Olympic-Committee-USA-Gymnastics-470969223.html|title=Michigan State President Resigns; US Olympic Committee Face Fallout of Larry Nassar Sentencing|work=NBC Chicago|date=January 24, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-nassar-accountability-20180124-story.html|title=Michigan State University president resigns amid widening calls for accountability over Larry Nassar abuse scandal|work=Los Angeles Times|date=January 24, 2018|first=Matt|last=Pearce}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/01/15/us/larry-nassar-gymnastics-me-too-sentence/index.html|title=Larry Nassar's sexual abuse victims finally get their days in court|work=CNN|date=January 15, 2018|first=Eric|last=Levenson}}</ref> and are named as defendants in civil lawsuits that former gymnasts have filed against Nassar.<ref name=chicagotri>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/international/ct-usa-gymnastics-fbi-doctor-abuse-20170216-story.html|title=USA Gymnastics alerted FBI in 2015 to doctor accused of abuse|work=Chicago Tribune|date=February 16, 2017|first1=Rick|last1=Maese|first2=Will|last2=Hobson}}</ref><ref name=nytsteve/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/14/sports/olympics/sexual-abuse-charges-put-shadow-on-us-gymnastics-federation.html|title=Sexual Abuse Charges Put Shadow on U.S. Gymnastics Federation|work=The New York Times|date=September 13, 2016|first=Juliet|last=Macur}}</ref>
Besides Nassar, other coaches across the country were involved in the scandal, in localities such as Michigan, Pennsylvania, California, Rhode Island, and Indiana.<ref name="TIS2016">{{cite web|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/news/2016/12/15/20-year-toll-368-gymnasts-allege-sexual-exploitation/95198724/|title=A 20-year toll: 368 gymnasts allege sexual exploitation|year=2016|publisher=[[The Indianapolis Star]]|language=English|accessdate=17 February 2018|author=Tim Evans, Mark Alesia and Marisa Kwiatkowski}}</ref>
On May 16, 2018, it was announced that the survivors would be awarded the [[Arthur Ashe Courage Award]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/olympics/2018/05/16/larry-nassar-victims-arthur-ashe-award-espy|title=Larry Nassar Sexual Assault Survivors to Receive Arthur Ashe Award For Courage At ESPYs|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=May 16, 2018}}</ref>
==Background== In 1990, USAG started a list of permanently banned coaches, including for sex abuse. In 1992, Robert Dean Head, a USAG coach in Kentucky, pled guilty to raping a 12-year old. In 2007, USAG made background checks mandatory for all coaches. [[Don Peters]], the national coach for the [[Gymnastics at the 1984 Summer Olympics|1984 Olympic team]], was banned from USAG in 2011, after two former gymnasts accused him of sexual abuse. In 2016, Olympic team doctor Larry Nassar was arrested on charges of sex abuse and possession of child pornography. Multiple victims of sexual abuse have filed lawsuits against USAG and other parties.<ref name=legacy>{{Cite news| title = A Legacy of Inaction| work = The Washington Post| accessdate = 2018-02-04| date = 2017-02-15| url = https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-40467147.html|via=High Beam}}</ref>
There have been several incidents where USA Gymnastics has dismissed warnings about coaches. In a 2013 lawsuit USA Gymnastics officials admitted under oath that allegations of sexual abuse were routinely dismissed as hearsay, unless they came directly from a victim or victim's parent. USA Gymnastics waited for four years before reporting Marvin Sharp to police. He was charged and committed suicide in prison. Mark Schiefelbein was charged in 2002 for molesting a 10-year-old girl. After prosecutors [[subpoena]]ed records, they learned that USA gymnastics had received prior complaints against Schiefelbein, who is serving a 36-year sentence. There had been a complaint about James Bell on file for at least five years before he was arrested in 2003 for molesting three young gymnasts. Bell pleaded guilty and is serving eight years in prison.<ref name=dayton />
At least four complaints were made against [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] coach William McCabe, but USAG did not report the allegations to police. One gym owner had warned that McCabe "should be locked in a cage before someone is raped". McCabe continued coaching for seven years, until one gymnast's mother went to the FBI with emails that had been sent to her 11-year-old daughter. McCabe was charged with molesting gymnasts, secretly videotaping girls changing clothes and posting their naked pictures on the Internet. He pleaded guilty and is serving a 30-year sentence.<ref name=dayton>{{Cite news| last1 = Kwiatkowski| first1 = Marisa Mark Alesia| last2 = Alesia| first2 = Mark| last3 = Star| first3 = Evans| title = A BLIND EYE TO SEX ABUSE ; How USA Gymnastics Protected Coaches over Kids by Failing to Report Allegations of Misconduct| work = Dayton Daily News (Dayton, OH)| accessdate = 2018-02-04| date = 2016-08-04| url = https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-39900495.html |via=High Beam}}</ref>
A judge released over 5,600 pages of court records in the McCabe case after the ''Indianapolis Star'' requested the documents, which detail how USA Gymnastics has responded to various sexual misconduct allegations that were made against coaches over a 10-year period from 1996 to 2006. The released documents included a letter which says a USAG regional chairman spoke to the organization's president in support of allowing a convicted sex offender to keep his membership. Other documents include sexual abuse complaints that were filed against 54 coaches. The documents revealed that some of coaches were not banned from the sport despite being convicted of the crimes. USAG has since said that it has banned 37 of the 54 coaches.<ref>{{Cite news| last1 = Kwiatkowski| first1 = Marisa| last2 = Evans| first2 = Tim| last3 = Alesia| first3 = Mark| last4 = Star| first4 = The Indianapolis| title = Judge Releases USA Gymnastics Sex Abuse Files| work = Dayton Daily News (Dayton, OH)| accessdate = 2018-02-04| date = 2017-03-05| url = https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-40514599.html|via=High Beam}}</ref>
In a deposition, then USAG President [[Steve Penny]] said "To the best of my knowledge, there's no duty to report if you are – if you are a third-party to some allegation ... You know, that lies with the person who has first-hand knowledge."<ref name=dayton /> Penny resigned in March 2017.<ref>{{Cite web| title = A list of all the USA Gymnastics board members who have resigned| work = Indianapolis Star| accessdate = 2018-02-04| url = https://www.indystar.com/story/news/2018/02/02/heres-list-all-usa-gymnastics-board-members-who-have-resigned/300714002/}}</ref>
[[Larry Nassar]] was a licensed [[osteopathic physician]] and the [[United States women's national gymnastics team|national team]] sports-medicine doctor for USA Gymnastics.<ref name=nytimes1>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/22/sports/olympics/usa-gymnastics-doctor-larry-nassar-sexual-assault-charges.html|title=Former USA Gymnastics Doctor Faces New Sexual Assault Charges|work=The New York Times|date=February 22, 2017|first=Victor|last=Mather}}</ref><ref name=timemckayla>{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4988116/larry-nassar-mckayla-maroney-sexual-abuse-doctor-usa-gymnastics/|title=Who Is Larry Nassar, the Former USA Gymnastics Doctor McKayla Maroney Accused of Sexual Abuse?|work=Time|date=October 18, 2017|first=Alice|last=Park}}</ref> He also ran a clinic and gymnastics club at [[Michigan State University]],<ref name=nytimes1/> where he was a faculty member.<ref name=chicagotri/> USAG fired Nassar in 2015 "after learning of athlete concerns".<ref name=nassarfired>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/dr-larry-nassar-accused-abuse-olympic-gymnast-fired-n651461|title=Dr. Larry Nassar, Accused of Abuse by Olympic Gymnast, Is Fired|work=NBC News|date=September 20, 2016}}</ref>
==Sexual abuse allegations== In September 2016, ''[[The Indianapolis Star]]'' revealed that [[Rachael Denhollander]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.indystar.com/videos/news/2016/09/12/90274492/|title=Gymnast accuses former USAG doctor of abuse|website=Indianapolis Star|language=en|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref> was one of two former gymnasts who had made accusations of sexual abuse against Nassar. Following those criminal complaints, Michigan State University reassigned Nassar from his clinical and teaching duties and fired him later that month.<ref name=nassarfired /> Since then, over 250 women and girls have accused Nassar of sexually abusing them.<ref name = "hundreds"/><ref name=indystartim>{{cite web|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/news/2016/09/12/former-usa-gymnastics-doctor-accused-abuse/89995734/|title=Former USA Gymnastics doctor accused of abuse|work=The Indianapolis Star|date=October 18, 2017|first=Tim|last=Evans}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/01/24/us/larry-nassar-sentencing/index.html|title=Larry Nassar sentenced to up to 175 years in prison for decades of sexual abuse|work=CNN|date=January 24, 2018|first=Eric|last=Levenson}}</ref><ref name=nyt1>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/24/sports/larry-nassar-sentencing.html|title=Larry Nassar Sentencing: 'I Just Signed Your Death Warrant'|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 24, 2018|first1=Scott|last1=Cacciola|first2=Victor|last2=Mather}}</ref> According to those reports, Nassar committed sexual assaults during medical examinations. The molestations ranged from inserting a finger in the gymnasts' vaginas and anuses to fondling their breasts and genitalia. These were criminal acts irrespective of consent, because the victims were minors. Nassar initially denied the charges, claiming that he was performing legitimate medical procedures.<ref name=chicagotri/> In February 2017, three former gymnasts, [[Jeanette Antolin]], Jessica Howard and [[Jamie Dantzscher]], gave an interview with ''[[60 Minutes]]'' in which they accused Nassar of sexually abusing them. The gymnasts also alleged that the "emotionally abusive environment" at the national team training camps run by [[Béla Károlyi|Béla]] and [[Márta Károlyi]] at the [[Karolyi Ranch]] near [[Huntsville, Texas]], gave Nassar an opportunity to take advantage of the gymnasts and made them afraid to speak up about the abuse.<ref name=60mins>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/on-60-minutes-former-gymnasts-allege-sexual-abuse/|title=On 60 Minutes, former gymnasts allege sexual abuse|work=CBS News|date=February 19, 2017|first=Brit|last=McCandless}}</ref> Rachael Denhollander, one of the first women to publicly accuse Nassar,<ref name=nyt1/> said in court in May 2017 that Nassar sexually abused her on five doctor's visits in 2000, when she was 15 years of age.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/13/us/michigan-gymnastics-doctor-sexual-abuse-allegations/index.html|title=Doctor's accuser: 'I froze, because I knew it was sexual abuse'|author1=Steve Almasy|author2=Anne Woolsey|work=CNN|date=May 14, 2017|accessdate=December 4, 2017}}</ref>
Olympic gold medalist [[McKayla Maroney]], using the [[Me Too movement|#MeToo hashtag]] on [[Twitter]], said that Nassar repeatedly molested her, starting when she was 13 years old and until she retired from the sport in 2016.<ref name=timemckayla/> Maroney filed a lawsuit against Nassar, Michigan State University, the [[United States Olympic Committee]] and USAG.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-maroney-gynnastics-settlement-20171220-story.html|title=McKayla Maroney accuses USOC and USA Gymnastics of covering up sexual abuse with secret settlement|work=[[LA Times]]|date=December 20, 2017}}</ref> The lawsuit accused USAG of covering up the sexual abuse by paying Maroney $1.25 million to sign a non-disclosure agreement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/olympics/gymnastics/story/_/id/21825575/usa-gymnastics-struck-agreement-mckayla-maroney-keep-larry-nassar-abuse-quiet-lawyer-says|title=USA Gymnastics struck deal with McKayla Maroney to keep Larry Nassar abuse quiet, lawyer says|work=[[ESPN]]|date=December 20, 2017}}</ref>
During a ''[[60 Minutes]]'' interview, Olympic gold medalist [[Aly Raisman]] also accused Nassar of sexually abusing her.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/aly-raisman-says-she-was-sexually-abused-by-u-s-national-team-doctor/|title=Aly Raisman says she was sexually abused by U.S. national team doctor|work=CBS News|date=November 10, 2017}}</ref> Raisman stated that Nassar molested her when she was 15 years of age.<ref name=cnnnasser /> Gabby Douglas drew criticism from fellow Olympic teammate [[Simone Biles]] and others for sending a tweet that they interpreted as criticizing Raisman and of "victim-shaming",<ref name=cnnnasser /> stating that "dressing in a provocative/sexual way incites the wrong crowd".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/nov/18/gabby-douglas-sorry-simone-biles-modest-dress|title=Gabby Douglas apologizes after Simone Biles calls out victim shaming tweet|author=Guardian sport|date=November 19, 2017|accessdate=December 4, 2017|work=The Guardian}}</ref> Douglas later apologized for the tweet,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2017/11/21/gabby-douglas-opens-up-in-aly-raisman-apology-i-was-abused-too/|title=Gabby Douglas opens up in Aly Raisman apology: I was abused, too|date=November 22, 2017|work=New York Post|accessdate=December 4, 2017|first=Hannah|last=Withiam}}</ref> and said she was also a victim of Nassar's alleged abuse.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/21/sports/gabby-douglas-sex-abuse.html|title=Gabby Douglas Says She Also Was Abused by Gymnastics Team Doctor|last=Stevens|first=Matt|date=November 21, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=November 22, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
