==Criminal proceedings== ===Larry Nassar=== In November 2016, Nassar was initially charged with sexual assault of a child.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chowdhury|first1=Saj|title=USA Gymnastics: How the sport has become beset by allegations of sex abuse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/gymnastics/38266205|accessdate=January 25, 2018|work=BBC Sport|date=December 16, 2016}}</ref> Michigan attorney general [[Bill Schuette]] stated that the assaults began when the victim was 6 years old in 1998, to 2005.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ex-USA Gymnastics doctor pleads not guilty to child sex charges|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/larry-nassar-ex-usa-gymnastics-doctor-pleads-not-guilty-to-child-sex-charges/|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=January 25, 2018|language=en|date=November 22, 2016}}</ref> He pleaded not guilty to three charges of first-degree criminal sexual conduct against a minor during his first court appearance. The following month, he was also indicted on federal [[child pornography]] charges. According to the FBI, over 37,000 images and videos of child pornography were seized from Nassar's home, including a [[GoPro]] video of Nassar allegedly molesting girls in a swimming pool.<ref name=NbcFBI>{{citenews|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/gymnastics-doctor-larry-nassar-hit-new-sex-abuse-claim-n698741|title=FBI Says Gymnastics Doctor Larry Nassar Recorded Abuse on Go Pro|first=Tracy|last=Connor|work=[[NBC News]]|date= December 21, 2016|accessdate=October 19, 2017}}</ref> Nassar pleaded guilty to three federal child pornography charges on July 11, 2017,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lansingstatejournal.com/story/news/local/2017/07/11/larry-nassar-child-porn-guilty-plea/463796001/|title=Nassar pleads guilty to federal child porn charges|work=[[Lansing State Journal]]|date=July 11, 2017|first=Matt|last=Mencarini}}</ref> and was given three consecutive 20-year prison sentences by U.S. District Judge [[Janet T. Neff]] on December 7, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lansingstatejournal.com/story/news/local/2017/12/07/larry-nassar-sentenced-60-years-federal-child-pornography-case/908838001/|title=Larry Nassar sentenced to 60 years in federal child pornography case|work=[[Lansing State Journal]]|publisher=|date=December 7, 2017|accessdate=January 3, 2018|first1=Justin A.|last1=Hinkley|first2=Beth|last2=LeBlanc}}</ref>
On November 15, 2017, it was announced that Nassar would plead guilty to counts of sexual assault in [[Ingham County, Michigan|Ingham County]] (which contains most of [[East Lansing, Michigan|East Lansing]], the home city for Michigan State) and [[Eaton County, Michigan|Eaton County]] in Michigan.<ref name=nassergulty>{{cite web|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/news/local/2017/11/15/nassar-plead-guilty-ingham-county-sex-assault-case/865934001/|title=Nassar to plead guilty in Ingham, Eaton sex assault cases|work=The Indianapolis Star|date=November 15, 2017|accessdate=December 4, 2017|first=Matt|last=Mencarini}}</ref> At the time, he faced a total of 22 charges, 15 in Ingham and 7 in Eaton. Among the allegations was that under the guise of providing legitimate treatment, he had instead molested 7 girls at his home and at a clinic on the MSU campus.<ref name=nasserguilty>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2017/11/21/larry-nassar-usa-gymnastics-expected-plead-guilty-sexual-assault/886906001/|title=AP: Larry Nassar expected to plead guilty, faces at least 25 years in prison|work=USA Today|date=November 21, 2017|accessdate=December 4, 2017|first=Heather|last=Tucker}}</ref> It also stated that Nassar would enter a guilty plea in Ingham County on November 22 and would then plead guilty in Eaton County on November 29 and would serve at least 25 years in prison for these crimes.<ref name=nassergulty /><ref name=nasserguilty /> Others who reported assaults by Nassar to the police were permitted to make victim impact statements during sentencing.<ref name=cnnnasser />
During his appearance before Judge [[Rosemarie Aquilina]] in Ingham County Circuit Court,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lansingstatejournal.com/story/news/local/2017/11/22/larry-nassar-plea-hearing-live/885846001/|title=Recap: Larry Nassar in court for plea hearing|work=Lansing State Journal|date=November 22, 2017|first=Matt|last=Mencarini|accessdate=December 4, 2017}}</ref> and under the terms of his [[plea bargain|plea agreement]], Nassar pleaded guilty to seven counts of criminal sexual conduct charges with a minimum sentence of 25 to 40 years in prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ex-olympics-doctor-larry-nassar-pleads-guilty-sex-charges-n823276|title=Ex-Olympics doctor Larry Nassar pleads guilty to sex charges|work=NBC News|date=November 22, 2017|first=Tracy|last=Connor|accessdate=December 4, 2017}}</ref> Three of the victims were under the age of 13 and three ranged in age from 13 to 15.<ref name=cnnnasser>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/22/us/us-gymnastics-doctor-plea-hearing/index.html|title=Ex-USA Gymnastics doctor pleads guilty to criminal sexual conduct|author1=Nicole Chavez|author2=Eric Levenson|work=CNN|date=November 23, 2017|accessdate=December 4, 2017}}</ref> Nassar issued a short statement in which he apologized and said that he was hopeful the community could move forward: "For all those involved, I'm so horribly sorry that this was like a match that turned into a forest fire out of control. I have no animosity toward anyone. I just want healing. ... We need to move forward in a sense of growth and healing and I pray (for) that".<ref>{{cite web|title=Ex-USA Gymnastics doctor Larry Nassar pleads guilty, faces at least 25 years|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/larry-nassar-usa-gymnastics-doctor-pleads-guilty-sex-charges-faces-at-least-25-years-prison/|work=CBS News|date=November 22, 2017|accessdate=January 25, 2018|language=en}}</ref> More than 150 women made statements during his week-long sentencing hearing before Nassar was handed a state prison sentence of 40 to 175 years on January 24, 2018. During his federal sentencing, Judge Neff had previously ordered that any state prison term run consecutive with Nassar's federal sentence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2017/12/ex-msu_olympics_doctor_larry_n.html|title=Ex-Olympics doctor Larry Nassar sentenced to 60 years on child porn|publisher=}}</ref> Judge Aquilina quoted a letter he sent her prior to sentencing, in which he blamed his accusers. She described him as a dangerous individual who showed little remorse and said that she "signed [his] death warrant".<ref name="nytimessentencing">{{cite web | last1 = Cacciola | first1 = Scott | last2 = Mather | first2 = Victor | title = Dr. Larry Nassar Sentenced to 40 to 175 Years for Sexual Abuse | publisher = The New York Times | date = January 24, 2018 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/24/sports/larry-nassar-sentencing.html | accessdate = January 24, 2018 }}</ref>
During his Eaton County Circuit Court appearance, Nassar pleaded guilty to engaging in sexual misconduct with three children under the age of 16.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ex-gymnastics-doctor-larry-nassar-pleads-guilty-3-more-criminal-n824861|title=Ex-gymnastics doctor Nassar pleads guilty to additional sex charges|work=NBC News|date=November 29, 2017|first=Kalhan|last=Rosenblatt|accessdate=December 4, 2017}}</ref> On February 5, 2018, Judge Janet Cunningham sentenced Nassar to an additional 40 to 125 years in state prison. This sentence will run consecutive to Nassar's federal sentence but concurrent to his previous state sentence from Ingham County.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/former-sports-doctor-sentenced-to-40-to-125-years-in-prison/ar-BBIJe8Z|title=Former sports doctor sentenced to 40 to 125 years in prison.|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/olympics/gymnastics/story/_/id/22331187/larry-nassar-sentenced-40-125-years-eaton-county|title=Nassar receives final sentence: 40 to 125 years|publisher=}}</ref>
===Steve Penny=== On October 17, 2018, former [[USA Gymnastics]] CEO [[Steve Penny]] was arrested on charge of evidence tampering in Larry Nassar case. He was accused of removing documents linked to the Larry Nassar sexual abuse case from the Karolyi Ranch gymnastics training facility in Texas.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/18/us/usa-gymnastics-former-president-steve-penny-arrest/index.html|title=Former USA Gymnastics president arrested on charge of evidence tampering in Larry Nassar case|work=[[CNN]]|date=October 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/2018/10/18/former-usa-gymnastics-ceo-accused-removing-files-karolyi-ranch/1680089002/|title=Former USA Gymnastics CEO Steve Penny arrested, indicted for tampering with evidence|work=[[USA Today]]|date=October 18, 2018}}</ref> On October 29 Penny entered a plea of not guilty.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/local/michigan/2018/10/29/steve-penny-usa-gymnastics-guilty-plea/38323681/|title=Ex-USA Gymnastics head pleads not guilty|work=[[The Detroit News]]|date=October 29, 2018}}</ref>
===Lou Anna Simon=== On November 20, 2018, former [[Michigan State University]] president [[Lou Anna Simon]] was charged with two felonies and two misdemeanor counts for lying to police. She is accused of falsely telling investigators she did not know the nature of a [[Title IX]] complaint against Nassar in 2014. She could face up to four years in prison on each felony charge.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/20/us/lou-anna-simon-michigan-state-nassar.html | title=Ex-President of Michigan State Charged With Lying About Nassar Case | date=November 20, 2018 | publisher=New York Times}}</ref>
==Response and impact== ===USA Gymnastics=== With regard to the USA Gymnastics sex abuse scandal in its entirety, USAG stated that "Nothing is more important to USA Gymnastics, the Board of Directors and CEO Steve Penny than protecting athletes, which requires sustained vigilance by everyone — coaches, athletes, parents, administrators and officials. We are saddened when any athlete has been harmed in the course of his or her gymnastics career."<ref name="TIS2016"/> The USAG also said that it required criminal background checks for all of its coaches.<ref name="TIS2016"/> An independent investigation by ''[[The Indianapolis Star]]'', however, found that "some coaches are fired at gym after gym without being tracked or flagged by USA Gymnastics, or losing their membership with the organization".<ref name="TIS2016"/>
Specifically with respect to Nassar, USA Gymnastics (USAG) said that its executives first learned of an athlete's concern regarding him in June 2015. Following an investigation, Nassar was fired and reported to the [[FBI]] in July 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2017/02/16/a03f968c-f489-11e6-a9b0-ecee7ce475fc_story.html|title=USA Gymnastics says it alerted FBI to doctor accused of sex abuse in 2015|work=The Washington Post|date=February 16, 2017|first1=Rick|last1=Maese|first2=Will|last2=Hobson}}</ref> In March 2017, USAG president [[Steve Penny]] resigned amid accusations of negligence<ref name=nytsteve>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/16/sports/steve-penny-resigns-as-usa-gymnastics-president.html|title=Steve Penny Resigns as U.S.A. Gymnastics President|work=The New York Times|date=March 16, 2017|first=John|last=Branch}}</ref> and calls for his dismissal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-gymnastics-president-20170316-story.html|title=USA Gymnastics President Steve Penny resigns amid abuse scandal|work=Los Angeles Times|date=March 16, 2017|first=David|last=Wharton}}</ref> In response to the scandal, USAG adopted reforms based on a June 2017 report by an investigator hired to review the organization's policies and practices. One of the changes is a requirement that all USAG members report any suspected sexual misconduct to appropriate authorities and the US Center for SafeSport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/06/27/health/usa-gymnastics-policy-changes/index.html|title=USA Gymnastics agrees to dozens of changes amid sex abuse scandal|date=June 27, 2017|work=CNN|first=Holly|last=Yan}}</ref>
USAG has received criticism over its handling of the sexual abuse allegations against Nassar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/mar/16/usa-gymnastics-president-steve-penny-resigns|title=USA Gymnastics head resigns amid pressure over handling of abuse cases|work=The Guardian|date=March 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/bobcook/2017/10/18/metoo-mckayla-maroney-says-she-was-among-the-many-molested-by-usa-gymnastics-team-doctor/#676c86213418|title=#MeToo: McKayla Maroney Says She Was Among the Many Molested by USA Gymnastics Team Doctor|work=Forbes|date=October 18, 2017|first=Bob|last=Cook}}</ref> According to a 2016 investigation reported by ''[[The Indianapolis Star]]'', top executives at USAG routinely dismissed sexual abuse allegations against coaches and failed to alert authorities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/news/investigations/2016/08/04/usa-gymnastics-sex-abuse-protected-coaches/85829732/|title=A blind eye to sex abuse: How USA Gymnastics failed to report cases|work=The Indianapolis Star|date=August 4, 2016|first1=Marisa|last1=Kwiatkowski|first2=Mark|last2=Alesia|first3=Tim|last3=Evans}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2016/09/13/gymnasts-accuse-ex-usa-gymnastics-doctor-of-sexual-abuse/|title=U.S. gymnasts accuse ex-team doctor of sexual abuse|work=The Washington Post|date=September 13, 2016|first=Derek|last=Hawkins}}</ref> [[United States Senate|United States Senators]] criticized the organization's leadership for waiting five weeks before reporting Nassar to authorities after first learning of allegations involving Nassar in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/doctor-at-center-of-usa-gymnastics-scandal-left-warning-signs-at-michigan-state/2017/04/25/eed48834-2530-11e7-a1b3-faff0034e2de_story.html|title=Doctor at center of USA Gymnastics scandal left warning signs at Michigan State|work=The Washington Post|date=April 25, 2017|first=Will|last=Hobson}}</ref> Juliet Macur of ''[[The New York Times]]'' was critical of USAG for not attending the 2017 congressional hearing on protecting young athletes from sexual abuse, and noted that the organization had not apologized for its role in the scandal.<ref name=nytimessenate/> Two-time Olympian [[Aly Raisman]] was also critical of USAG's response to the scandal, pointing out that the reported $1 million [[severance package]] given to former president Penny could have been used to create a program to help the affected athletes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/aug/20/aly-raisman-usa-gymnastics-larry-nassar-sexual-abuse-allegations|title=Olympic champion Aly Raisman attacks USAG over sexual abuse case|work=The Guardian|date=August 20, 2017}}</ref>
Amid the sex abuse scandal, USAG lost several major corporate sponsors, including [[Procter & Gamble]], [[Kellogg's]], [[Under Armour]], [[The Hershey Company]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/12/14/amid-sexual-assault-scandal-usa-gymnastics-loses-major-corporate-sponsors|title=Amid sexual assault scandal, USA Gymnastics loses major corporate sponsors|work=The Washington Post|date=December 14, 2017|first=Des|last=Bieler}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/olympics/gymnastics/story/_/id/21778336/under-armour-hersheys-procter-gamble-ending-sponsorship-contracts-usa-gymnastics|title=Under Armour, Hershey's, Procter & Gamble ending sponsorships of USA Gymnastics|work=ESPN|date=December 16, 2017|first=Darren|last=Rovell}}</ref> and [[AT&T]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2018/01/23/att-suspends-usa-gymnastics-sponsorship-sexual-abuse-scandal-nassar/1057136001/|title=AT&T suspends USA Gymnastics sponsorship, cites sexual abuse scandal|work=[[USA Today]]|date=January 23, 2018|first1=Rachel|last1=Axon|first2=Nancy|last2=Armour}}</ref> Procter & Gamble was the name sponsor of the [[USA Gymnastics National Championships|National Championships]] for five seasons, AT&T sponsored the [[American Cup]] since 2011, and Kellogg's sponsored a series nationwide tours. Marketing revenues account for approximately 35% of USAG annual revenues, or about $9.4 million. Kellogg's and Procter & Gamble were two of the largest sponsors associated with the organization.<ref>{{Cite news| last = Reid| first = Scott| title = Procter & Gamble, Kellogg's Drop USA Gymnastics Sponsorship after Sex Abuse Scandal| work = Redlands Daily Facts| accessdate = 2018-02-04| date = 2017-12-14| url = https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P4-1977187666.html}}</ref>
In January 2018, USAG officially cut ties with [[Karolyi Ranch]], the former national training center for the [[United States women's national gymnastics team|national team]] and a site where Nassar sexually assaulted many gymnasts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/olympics/story/_/id/22145103/usa-gymnastics-cuts-ties-karolyi-ranch-training-facility|title=USA Gymnastics cuts ties with Karolyi Ranch training facility|work=[[ESPN]]|date=January 18, 2018|first1=Dan|last1=Murphy|first2=John|last2=Barr}}</ref> Later that month the Karolyi Ranch announced on its website that the facility had permanently closed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.khou.com/news/local/texas/karolyi-ranch-closes-remains-under-investigation-after-sex-abuse-allegations/511605072|title=Karolyi Ranch closes, remains under investigation after sex abuse allegations|last=Dougherty|first=Matt|date=January 25, 2018|work=[[KHOU]], Houston, Texas|publisher=[[Tegna, Inc.]]|accessdate=January 26, 2018}}</ref> On January 22, 2018, three members of the USAG Board of Directors resigned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://usagym.org/pages/post.html?PostID=21213&prog=h|title=USA Gymnastics statement regarding Board of Directors Executive Leadership|work=[[USA Gymnastics]]|date=January 22, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2018/01/22/usa-gymnastics-top-leadership-resigns-amid-sexual-abuse-scandal/1054233001/|title=USA Gymnastics top leadership resigns amid sexual abuse scandal|work=[[USA Today]]|date=January 22, 2018|first=Nancy|last=Armour}}</ref> Following Nassar's sentencing on January 24, 2018, the [[United States Olympic Committee]] (USOC) published an [[open letter]] calling for the resignations of the remaining USAG Board of Directors, stating that failure to comply with the request would result in the USOC taking steps to decertify the governing body. The USOC also announced that it was launching a third-party investigation into the scandal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbssports.com/olympics/news/usoc-entire-usa-gymnastics-board-must-resign-over-larry-nassar-sex-abuse-scandal/|title=USOC: Entire USA Gymnastics board must resign over Larry Nassar sex abuse scandal|work=CBS Sports|date=January 24, 2018|first=Pete|last=Blackburn}}</ref> On January 31, USAG received resignations from every member of its Board of Directors, complying with USOC's demands.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://usagym.org/pages/post.html?PostID=21261&prog=h|title=USA Gymnastics statement regarding Board resignations|work=[[USA Gymnastics]]|date=January 31, 2018}}</ref>
On February 1, it was revealed that the USOC was aware of the abuse claims in 2015, prior to when they claim they first learned of it in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/olympics/2018/02/01/usoc-gymnasts-abuse-allegations|title=Report: USOC Didn't Act on Gymnasts' Abuse Claims in 2015|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=February 1, 2018}}</ref> Reports surfaced that then-USAG President Steve Penny called USOC Chief Executive Scott Blackmun in July 2015 revealing that an investigation uncovered possible criminal behavior by Nassar against Olympic athletes. Additionally in September, 2015, Penny emailed USOC Security Chief detailing the allegations against Nassar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/olympics-officials-didnt-act-on-gymnasts-abuse-allegations-in-2015-1517484720|title=Olympics Committee Failed to Act on Nassar's Alleged Abuse for a Full Year|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=February 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/sports/u-s-olympic-committee-didnt-act-on-gymnasts-claims-against-larry-nassar-in-2015-report/?xid=socialflow_twitter_peoplemag|title=U.S. Olympic Committee Didn't Act on Gymnasts' Claims Against Larry Nassar in 2015: Report|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=February 1, 2018}}</ref>
[[John Geddert]], team coach of the 2012 London Olympic team and personal coach of [[Jordyn Wieber]], retired following an announcement by USAG that he had been suspended as a result of his connection to Nassar. Geddert operated two gyms that employed Nassar, including Twistars.<ref>{{Cite web| last = News| first = A. B. C.| title = USA Gymnastics suspends former Olympics coach with ties to Larry Nassar| work = ABC News| accessdate = 2018-02-04| date = 2018-01-23| url = http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/usa-gymnastics-suspends-olympics-coach-ties-larry-nassar/story?id=52548744}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| last = Eggert| first = David| title = Abuse victims say they were required by owner of Michigan gymnastics club to see Larry Nassar| work = chicagotribune.com| accessdate = 2018-02-04| url = http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/international/ct-larry-nassar-john-geddert-twistars-20180202-story.html}}</ref> Ownership of Twistars has been transferred to Geddert's wife Katherine. Gymnasts have reported being abused by Nassar at Twistars.<ref>{{Cite web| last = Eggert| first = David| title = Molested gymnasts blast coach who sent them to Larry Nassar| work = chicagotribune.com| accessdate = 2018-02-04| url = http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/international/ct-molested-gymnasts-blast-coach-who-sent-them-to-doctor-20180201-story.html}}</ref> Gymnasts have also accused Geddert of being abusive and dismissive of their injuries. One gymnast said Geddert had thrown her onto the low bar hard enough to tear the muscles in her stomach and end her career. They have said that Geddert's abuse left them vulnerable to Nassar's manipulation.<ref>{{Cite web| title = Ex-gymnast: Geddert 'deserves to be in jail'| work = ESPN.com| accessdate = 2018-02-04| date = 2018-01-24| url = http://www.espn.com/olympics/story/_/id/22202814}}</ref>
On February 2, [[Valeri Liukin]] resigned as national team coordinator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/olympics/gymnastics/story/_/id/22300776/valeri-liukin-steps-us-women-gymnastics-team-coordinator|title=Valeri Liukin steps down as U.S. women's gymnastics team coordinator|work=[[ESPN]]|date=February 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2018/02/02/valeri-liukin-resigning-role-u-s-womens-gymnastics-team/301243002/|title=Valeri Liukin resigning from role with U.S. women's gymnastics team|work=[[USA Today]]|date=February 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadspin.com/u-s-womens-gymnastics-coordinator-valeri-liukin-sudden-1822669851|title=U.S. Women's Gymnastics Coordinator Valeri Liukin Suddenly Resigns|work=[[Deadspin]]|date=February 2, 2018}}</ref> Later that month, the USOC CEO Scott Blackmun also resigned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/scott-blackmun-steps-down-as-us-olympic-committee-chief-executive/2018/02/28/742775b2-1cc2-11e8-9de1-147dd2df3829_story.html|title=Scott Blackmun steps down as U.S. Olympic Committee chief executive|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=February 28, 2018}}</ref>
On February 28, Raisman filed a lawsuit against USA Gymnastics and the USOC claiming both organizations "knew or should have known" about the ongoing abuse.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/gymnast-aly-raisman-sues-u-s-olympic-committee-over-nassar-n852541|title=Gymnast Aly Raisman sues U.S. Olympic Committee over Nassar abuse|work=[[NBC]]|date=March 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.in/olympics/story/_/id/22621847/aly-raisman-files-lawsuit-usoc-usa-gymnastics-larry-nassar-sexual-abuse-case|title=Aly Raisman files lawsuit against USOC, USA Gymnastics|work=[[ESPN]]|date=March 2, 2018}}</ref> On May 1, former national team member [[Sabrina Vega]] sued USAG, the USOC, and [[Béla Károlyi|Béla]] and [[Márta Károlyi]], claiming they ignored signs about Nassar's behavior or should have known he posed a risk to the gymnasts he treated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://olympics.nbcsports.com/2018/05/01/sabrina-vega-sues-usa-gymnastics-larry-nassar-karolyi/|title=World champion gymnast sues Karolyis, others over Larry Nassar abuse|work=[[NBC Sports]]|date=May 1, 2018}}</ref>
On September 4, USA Gymnastics CEO and President, Kerry Perry, resigned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://usagym.org/pages/post.html?PostID=22482&prog=|title=Letter to Membership from USA Gymnastics Board Chair Karen Golz|work=[[USA Gymnastics]]|date=September 4, 2018}}</ref> This came after USOC CEO Sarah Hirshland called for a change in USAG leadership<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2018/08/31/usoc-leader-sarah-hirshland-calls-ouster-usa-gymnastics-ceo-kerry-perry/1164309002/|title=USOC chief says it's time to consider USA Gymnastics CEO change as controversy continues|work=[[USA Today]]|date=August 31, 2018}}</ref> and the United States Elite Coaches Association called for a [[Motion of no confidence|vote of no confidence]] in Perry.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadspin.com/usa-gymnastics-is-imploding-1828764997|title=USA Gymnastics Is Imploding|work=[[Deadspin]]|date=September 2, 2018}}</ref> On October 12, [[Mary Bono]] was appointed interim president and chief executive officer of USA Gymnastics.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://usagym.org/pages/post.html?PostID=22720|title=The Honorable Mary Bono has been named interim president and chief executive officer of USA Gymnastics|work=[[USA Gymnastics]]|date=October 12, 2018}}</ref> She resigned four days later after many people, including Raisman and Biles, expressed criticism over choosing Bono as interim president due to her ties with her former law firm, [[Faegre Baker Daniels]], the same firm that helped cover up Nassar's crimes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/10/16/657941576/after-barrage-of-criticism-usa-gymnastics-interim-president-and-ceo-resigns|title=After Barrage Of Criticism, USA Gymnastics Interim President And CEO Resigns|work=[[NPR]]|date=October 16, 2018}}</ref>
On November 5, 2018, the USOC announced that it was starting the process to decertify USAG as the national governing body for gymnastics in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/11/05/us/usa-gymnastics-us-olympic-committee/index.html|title=US Olympic Committee moves to revoke USA Gymnastics' status|publisher=[[CNN]]|language=en-US|date=November 6, 2018|access-date=November 6, 2018}}</ref>
===Michigan State University=== Michigan State University said that it first received a complaint against Nassar in 2014. A Title IX investigation into the complaint found no violation of policy and Nassar was allowed to continue treating patients under certain agreed upon restrictions as stipulated by MSU College of Osteopathic Medicine Dean William Strampel. However no monitoring was instituted.<ref name="lsj">{{cite news|last1=Wolcott|first1=RJ|title=MSU president apologizes to Nassar victims; university creates $10 million counseling fund|url=https://www.lansingstatejournal.com/story/news/local/2017/12/15/msu-board-trustees-sexual-assault-simon-nassar-students/954984001/|accessdate=February 8, 2018|work=Lansing State Journal|date=December 15, 2017|language=en}}</ref> After allegations against Nassar were made public by ''[[The Indianapolis Star]]'' in September 2016, Nassar was fired by Michigan State for violating the 2014 agreement.<ref name=NbcFBI/>
The university faces lawsuits from 144 local and MSU athletes who say they were sexually assaulted by Larry Nassar.<ref name=klages>{{cite web|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/opinion/columnists/nolan-finley/2017/12/02/cost-msu-gymnast-scandal/108247652/|title=Finley: MSU cost in gymnast abuse scandal could top $1B|work=The Detroit News|date=December 2, 2017|first=Nolan|last=Finley}}</ref> Former Michigan State University gymnastics coach Kathie Klages was suspended on February 13, 2017, and retired the next day, amidst the sexual abuse investigation of Nassar.<ref name=klages2>{{cite web|url=http://statenews.com/article/2017/08/klages-twistars|title=Former MSU gymnastics coach Klages working at gymnastics club|work=The State News|date=August 27, 2017|first=Madison|last=O'Connor}}</ref> Klages has been accused of dismissing sexual abuse complaints by former gymnasts against Nassar and pressuring them to stay silent.<ref name=klages/> According to court documents, Klages was reportedly aware of sexual abuse allegations against Nassar as early as 1997.<ref name=klages2/>
On December 12, 2017, Strampel resigned as dean and went on medical leave as faculty. Mediation ended in the civil lawsuits. Thus the MSU Board of Trustees voted to establish a $10 million fund to reimburse victims of Nassar for counseling services. MSU President Lou Anna Simon also apologized to the Nassar victims and donated her just approved raise to the Roy J. and Lou Anna K. Simon Scholarship fund while declining it in the future. Kaylee Lorincz, Nassar's Ingham County criminal case "Victim E", addressed the board wanting the university to change not for them to focus on litigation. Lorincz did not think the apology was "heartfelt".<ref name="lsj"/>
During Nassar's sentencing in January 2018, 8 former MSU athletes, including those from the gymnastics, softball, volleyball, rowing, and track and field programs, gave [[victim impact statement]]s accusing MSU staff of dismissing their sexual abuse complaints against Nassar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lansingstatejournal.com/story/sports/college/msu/2018/01/25/ncaa-investigation-michigan-state-larry-nassar/1064105001/|title=Who'll be key figures at center of NCAA investigation at Michigan State?|date=January 25, 2018|work=Lansing State Journal|first=Chris|last=Solari}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2018/01/23/us/nassar-sexual-abuse-who-knew/index.html|title=What others knew: Culture of denial protected Nassar for years|work=CNN|date=January 25, 2018|first=Nicole|last=Chavez}}</ref> On January 23, 2018, the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] formally opened an investigation into the university's handling of sexual abuse allegations against Nassar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/23/sports/michigan-state-ncaa-investigation.html|title=N.C.A.A. Opens Investigation of Michigan State Over Nassar Case|work=The New York Times|date=January 23, 2018|first=Marc|last=Tracy}}</ref> On January 24, 2018, amid backlash over the university's role in the scandal, the [[Michigan House of Representatives]] voted overwhelmingly for a [[non-binding resolution]] sponsored by Rep. [[Adam Zemke]], that called for the university's Board of Trustees to fire President [[Lou Anna Simon]] if she did not resign. Simon resigned later that same day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/politics/2018/01/24/michigan-house-resolution-simon-resign/109777330/|title=MSU President Lou Anna Simon resigns|work=The Detroit News|date=January 24, 2018|first=Jonathan|last=Oosting}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20180125/news01/651021/msu-president-lou-anna-simon-resigns-in-wake-of-nassar-case|title=MSU President Lou Anna Simon resigns in wake of Nassar case|work=Crain's Detroit Business|date=January 24, 2018|first=Michael|last=Lee}}</ref> Two days later, MSU athletic director [[Mark Hollis (athletic director)|Mark Hollis]] retired.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/26/sports/michigan-state-mark-hollis.html|title=Michigan State Athletic Director Mark Hollis Resigns|work=The New York Times|date=January 26, 2018|first=Marc|last=Tracy}}</ref>
On January 27, 2018, [[ESPN]]'s ''[[Outside the Lines]]'' reported that their investigation "found a pattern of widespread denial, inaction and information suppression of such allegations by officials ranging from campus police to the Spartan athletic department" that went "well beyond" the Nassar case. According to the investigation, at least 16 [[Michigan State Spartans football|football]] players have been accused of sexual assault or violence against women since 2007, the team's first season under current head coach [[Mark Dantonio]]. The investigation also included two previously publicized allegations of similar conduct by members of the [[Michigan State Spartans men's basketball|men's basketball program,]] as well as one never-before-publicized allegation made by former Michigan State counselor Lauren Allswede against Travis Walton.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/espn/story/_/id/22214566/pattern-denial-inaction-information-suppression-michigan-state-goes-larry-nassar-case-espn |title=OTL: Michigan State secrets extend far beyond Larry Nassar case |first1=Paula |last1=Lavigne |first2=Nicole |last2=Noren |website=ESPN.com |date=January 27, 2018 |accessdate=January 27, 2018}}</ref> ESPN has been criticized for their reporting in linking these allegations to the Larry Nassar scandal by some members of the local and national media, especially for showing a graphic of Coach Dantonio, Coach Izzo, and Larry Nassar together with a title of "Crisis at Michigan State" in the Outside the Lines report.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theathletic.com/257847/2018/03/01/entering-tournament-msus-tom-izzo-wants-just-basketball-as-focus-for-team/|title=Entering tournament, Tom Izzo wants 'just basketball' as...|first=Katie|last=Strang|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/ncaa-football/news/michigan-state-interim-president-blasts-espn-dragging-mark-dantonio-tom-izzo-larry-nassar-scandal/kri4rtlsqsxk1cn8sux8kbbzv|title=Michigan State interim president blasts ESPN for dragging Mark Dantonio, Tom Izzo|date=February 13, 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lansingstatejournal.com/story/sports/columnists/graham-couch/2018/02/01/tom-izzo-espn-michigan-state-couch-column/1084253001/|title=Couch: Tom Izzo has chosen a standoff with ESPN – one he might win|publisher=}}</ref> Mark Dantonio denied all allegations on mishandling sexual assault<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbssports.com/college-football/news/watch-michigan-states-mark-dantonio-disputes-report-of-mishandled-sexual-assault-allegations/|title=WATCH: Michigan State's Mark Dantonio disputes report of mishandled sexual-assault allegations|publisher=}}</ref> and [[Tom Izzo]] insisted that he would cooperate with any investigation as he had in the past stating "we'll cooperate with any investigation and always have".<ref name="si.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/college-basketball/2018/01/28/tom-izzo-michigan-state-sexual-assault-investigation-questioning|title=Tom Izzo: "I cooperated with every investigation"|publisher=}}</ref> In 2017 with sexual assault charges facing 4 former Michigan State football players, Mark Dantonio was cleared by the independent report conducted by the Jones Day firm, however it was determined that football administrative staff member Curtis Blackwell had violated policy <ref name="si.com"/> and was let go. The report also determined that Coach Dantonio had actually been the one to report the alleged sexual assault involving three players when he had been informed of the assault by another player.<ref name="lansingstatejournal.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.lansingstatejournal.com/story/sports/college/msu/football/2017/06/05/kn/371675001/|title=Investigation clears MSU's Dantonio; Blackwell violated policy|publisher=}}</ref> The report found that Dantonio properly followed the mandatory reporting guidelines making several calls and texts to report the incident between 2:01 and 2:12 pm on January 16, 2017, including calls to MSU's director of the Office of Institutional Equity.<ref name="lansingstatejournal.com"/> On June 6, 2018, three of the four football players charged where sentenced to 36 months probation and ordered to undergo sexual offender therapy after agreeing to a plea to charges of [[seduction]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lansingstatejournal.com/story/news/local/2018/06/06/former-michigan-state-football-players-sentenced-probation/676220002/|title=3 former Michigan State football players sentenced to probation in sexual assault case|publisher=}}</ref>
Several other investigations by state and federal agencies into Michigan State's involvement are ongoing, including the Michigan Attorney General's office <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/index.ssf/2018/01/6_questions_schuette_didnt_ans.html|title=7 questions AG Bill Schuette needs to answer about his Michigan State investigation|publisher=}}</ref> and the United States Education Department.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/02/26/education-department-michigan-state-probe-425355|title=DeVos announces new Title IX probe at Michigan State|publisher=}}</ref> As a result of the Michigan Attorney General's investigation, in March 2018 William Strampel, who oversaw Nassar's clinic while dean of the [[Michigan State University College of Osteopathic Medicine|College of Osteopathic Medicine]], was arrested and charged with felony misconduct in office and criminal sexual conduct for allegedly groping a student and storing nude photos on his computer. Strampel also possessed a video of the pelvic floor manipulation procedure that was created as a training video by Larry Nassar. However, the video may constitute evidence of an assault, with investigations ongoing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/dean-william-strampel-michigan-state-university-arrested-larry-nassar-probe-arraignment-today/|title=William Strampel, former Michigan State University Dean, accused of storing nude photos|date=March 27, 2018|work=CBS News}}</ref> On June 9, 2018, six current or former Michigan State employees linked to Nassar became the subject of an investigation by Michigan's Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs. <ref name="ls">{{cite news|last1=Mencarini|first1=Matt|title=6 current, former MSU employees with ties to Nassar scandal under state licensing inquiries|url=https://www.lansingstatejournal.com/story/news/local/2018/06/08/larry-nassar-michigan-state-licensing-inquiries-strampel-hadden-teachnor-hauk-dietzel-stollak-msu/684359002/|accessdate=June 10, 2018|work=Lansing State Journal|date=June 8, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
On May 16, 2018, it was announced that the Michigan State University and Nassar victims had reached a $500 million settlement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory/michigan-state-nassar-victims-reach-500m-settlement-55207955?cid=clicksource_nc_breaking|title=ABC Sports News|first=ABC|last=News|website=ABC News}}</ref>
===United States Congress=== The [[United States Congress]] responded to the sexual abuse claims that were made against Nassar and also responded to claims made against personnel who were involved with [[USA Swimming]] and [[USA Taekwondo]]. [[United States Senator]] [[Dianne Feinstein]] introduced a bill that would require [[United States Olympic Committee#National Governing Body Members|national governing body]] members overseeing Olympic sports to immediately report sexual assault allegations to law enforcement or designated child-welfare agencies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.feinstein.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?id=DFAC8B0E-AB09-4176-8D74-B9D803CFAB2B|title=Senators Introduce Bill Requiring U.S. Amateur Athletic Organizations, Members to Report Sexual Abuse|website=feinstein.senate.gov|date=March 6, 2017}}</ref> Former gymnasts [[Dominique Moceanu]], [[Jamie Dantzscher]] and Jessica Howard testified at a [[Senate Judiciary Committee]] hearing on March 28, 2017, concerning the bill.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/former-usa-gymnasts-address-senators-at-hearing-on-young-athletes-and-abuse/|title=Olympic stars testify to Congress about sex abuse at USA Gymnastics program|work=CBS News|date=March 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name=nytimessenate>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/29/sports/facing-congress-some-sports-officials-not-all-begin-to-confront-sex-abuse.html|title=Facing Congress, Some Sports Officials (Not All) Begin to Confront Sexual Abuse|first=Juliet|last=Macur|date=March 29, 2017|work=The New York Times}}</ref> Rick Adams, chief of Paralympic sports for the [[United States Olympic Committee]] and head of organizational development for the NGBs, stated at the hearing: "We do take responsibility, and we apologize to any young athlete who has ever faced abuse." USAG was asked to testify at the hearing, but declined.<ref name=nytimessenate/>
The [[Protecting Young Victims from Sexual Abuse and Safe Sport Authorization of 2017|Protecting Young Victims from Sexual Abuse and Safe Sport Authorization Act of 2017]], a bipartisan bill sponsored by Senators [[Dianne Feinstein|Dianne Feinstein (D-C.A.)]] and [[John Thune| John Thune (R-S.D.)]] and others, was agreed to in the House of Representatives on January 29, 2018. The bill was agreed to in the Senate on January 30, 2018 and became law on February 14, 2018, when it was signed by President [[Donald J. Trump]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Actions - S.534 - 115th Congress (2017-2018): Protecting Young Victims from Sexual Abuse and Safe Sport Authorization Act of 2017 |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-bill/534/actions |website=www.congress.gov |language=en |date=14 February 2018}}</ref> Among other things, the law requires Olympic governing bodies and amateur sports organizations to report sex-abuse allegations immediately to local or federal law enforcement, or a child-welfare agency designated by the [[United States Department of Justice]]. It further authorizes the United States Center for Safe Sport to ensure that aspiring U.S. Olympic athletes can report allegations of abuse to an independent and non-conflicted entity for investigation and resolution, and to make sure that all national governing bodies follow the strictest standards for child abuse prevention and detection. The bill amends the [[Amateur Sports Act of 1978|Ted Stevens Olympic and Amateur Sports Act]], under the Commerce Committee’s jurisdiction, to expand the purposes of USOC to promote a safe environment in sports that is free from abuse.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.commerce.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2018/1/thune-and-nelson-statements-on-passage-of-safe-sport-authorization|title=Thune and Nelson Statements on Passage of Safe Sport Authorization|website=Senate Commerce Committee Press Release|date=January 20, 2018}}</ref>
